metadata.sermon_title: Face to Face, Hand in Hand
metadata.sermon_start_end: The Archbishop of Canterbury was quoted recently on the subject of e-mail and the Internet. He acknowledged the power and usefulness of the Net, but observed that a lot of people thought they were having real relationships by e-mail when in fact there can be no real relationships [...] our deteriorating human body for an altogether transformed one that will nevertheless be our very own and no one else's, a body with which to love others and be loved in return with all the love of Christ himself. 'Death is swallowed up in victory'. AMEN.

1_specific_bible_passage.findings: The sermon uses the text as a springboard for a general dogmatic defense of the 'resurrection of the body' against 'immortality of the soul'. While it stays within 1 Corinthians 15, it flits between verses 12, 35, 47, 49, and 54, as well as the Gospels of Mark, Matthew, and John. It fails to identify what is unique to verses 47-49 that cannot be found elsewhere.
quotes: St. Paul's letter to the church in Corinth addresses this issue head-on.
Paul, as he dictates, seems to sense that these illustrations from the natural world are not working so he abandons them and goes on to a much more arresting set of Biblical images.
1_specific_bible_passage.improvement_point: Focus exclusively on the 'man of dust' vs 'man of heaven' typology. What does this specific Adam-Christ contrast provide that the general resurrection argument in the rest of the chapter does not?

2_exegesis_original_context.findings: The preacher correctly identifies the Hellenistic context and the Corinthian tendency toward spiritualization. However, the exegesis is more thematic than linguistic or historical. There is no evidence of the 'Hebrew and Greek' requirement Dekker demands for a minister.
quotes: The Corinthian congregation... was turning away from the revolutionary Christian proclamation of the resurrection of the body. They were returning to the much more familiar religious idea of the immortality of the soul.
2_exegesis_original_context.improvement_point: Deepen the exegesis of 'choikos' (dusty/earthly) and 'epouranios' (heavenly) to show how Paul is reinterpreting Genesis in light of the Risen Christ.

3_application_concrete_contemporary.findings: The application is largely anecdotal (emails, Robert E. Lee, a Guatemalan Easter card) rather than a concrete analysis of the zeitgeist. It touches on human emotion (grief) but remains somewhat general in its 'spiritual' application.
quotes: I know two couples who met on the Internet...
Virginians think they love Robert E. Lee. They don't love Robert E. Lee; they love their image of Robert E. Lee.
3_application_concrete_contemporary.improvement_point: Move beyond anecdotes about 'relationships' to a sharper critique of modern Gnosticism or the digital 'disembodiment' of the person as a form of the 'man of dust's' misery.

4_interwoveness_exposition_application.findings: The sermon follows a pattern of 'textual observation' followed by 'illustrative anecdote'. While not strictly a two-block sermon, the application often feels like an external illustration brought to the text rather than the text 'expounding' the hearer.
quotes: The impact of the picture... came from the sight of the bloodied little limp body... Bodies matter. Faces matter.
4_interwoveness_exposition_application.improvement_point: Integrate the contemporary examples of 'bodily presence' directly into the explanation of the 'image of the man of heaven' so they are not merely parallel stories.

5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.findings: Misery is present in the form of death and the 'man of dust'. Redemption is clearly outside the self (God's action). Gratitude is expressed as the 'wonderful' hope of the resurrection. It is sufficiently Trinitarian.
quotes: if Christ has not been raised, your faith is futile and you are still in your sins.
our sinfulness exchanged for his righteousness, our mortality for his immortality.
5_three_parts_misery_redemption_gratitud.improvement_point: Sharpen the 'misery' aspect. The sermon treats the 'immortality of the soul' as a theological error; Dekker would suggest treating it as a form of human misery/lostness.

6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.findings: This is the weakest point. The sermon ends in a 'rapture' of universal-sounding hope. The possibility of being 'lost' (temporal or eternal) is mentioned only as a quote from Paul, but not applied as a serious choice for the hearer.
quotes: all our sins wiped away, all evil done to death forever... our loved ones restored to us.
6_two_ways_seriousness_of_choice.improvement_point: Address the consequence of remaining in the 'image of the man of dust'. If 'flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom', what is the gravity of the choice to reject the 'man of heaven'?

7_christocentric_grace.findings: Christ is clearly the telos. The sermon emphasizes that resurrection is God's work, not a natural process. The 'one Lord' is central to the resolution of the 'dust' dilemma.
quotes: the single, definitive, and unique action of God to vindicate and enthrone the crucified Messiah.
Man has no life in himself, it is Christ who is his life.
7_christocentric_grace.improvement_point: Ensure the 'two natures' of Christ are more explicitly linked to why He can be the 'second man' who transforms our dust.

8_depth_and_length.findings: At roughly 18 minutes (1850 words), the sermon falls just short of Dekker's 20-minute minimum. While it has some breadth, the frequent use of long quotes from multiple Gospels suggests a lack of sustained depth on the primary text.
8_depth_and_length.improvement_point: Expand the specific exposition of verses 47-49 to reach the 20-minute mark, replacing external anecdotes with deeper textual 'breadth'.

overall_assessment.summary: The sermon falls short of Dekkerâ€™s ideal primarily in its lack of textual specificity and its avoidance of the 'two ways'. It functions more as a topical lecture on the doctrine of the resurrection than a specific exposition of the 1 Corinthians 15:47-49 pericope. It relies heavily on anecdotes that, while engaging, do not always serve to 'expound' the hearer in light of the Word. However, its Christocentric focus and rejection of natural theology (the tulip analogy) align well with Barthian/Dekkerian priorities.
strengths: Strong Christocentric telos; grace is the final word.
Clear rejection of 'natural' resurrection analogies in favor of 'revelational' breakthrough.
Adequate backgrounding of the three parts (misery, redemption, gratitude).
weaknesses: Fails the 20-minute rule, lacking the 'breadth' required for true depth.
Insufficiently specific to the chosen pericope; too many 'keyword' jumps to other Bible books.
Absence of the 'two ways'; the seriousness of being lost is not actualized for the hearer.
overall_assessment.final_judgment_according_to_dekker: This is a 'satisfactory' attempt at a sermon, but it remains too much a 'speech about a biblical idea' (the resurrection) rather than a specific 'recreation of this Bible passage into a current word'. It lacks the sharp, concrete application and the existential weight of the 'two ways' that Dekker demands.
